Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2011 03:33PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: TonLee - Yeah, I am going to question the length of treatment.  My understanding is, and I could be wrong, the total amount of radiation used does not determine the length of treatment, it is the amount at each treatment that result in the number of treatments.  So the number of weeks could be shorter or longer depending upon how much they want to radiate you at each sitting.  If that makes sense. My cancer was not close to my chest wall.  With the BMX I had clear margins all around.  Only had cancer in my left breast, a small of amount of DCIS near my nipple and 1.3cm of IDC unifocal in the upper left quandrant, not close to the chest wall at all.  No other cancer found except in the 2 SN.  No LVI either.  Everything else in the pathology report was good.  Had at PET/CT scan after the BMX and it did not detect anything.  Everytime I ask an oncologist the question "If I had the ALND would you still radiate me?"  The answer is either "not sure, need to re-evaluate" or "No, we would not recommend radiation if the ALND came back with no other lymph nodes having cancer".  That is why I have been fighting the 'standard of care' with regards to radiating the chest wall. Sending you {{HUGS}} and hoping your healing and expansion goes well.

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2012 08:42AM ProudMom_Wife wrote: Hi rabbit - similiar situation, but also different. I was clinically node-negative going into my BMX, and the two positive nodes found were not found until the final pathology came in, so I had to decide about the ALND. I decided to decline for these reason which applied to my situation: a) Although 3 sentinel nodes were removed they also ended up taking an intramammary node and axillary node, both negative.   b) Only the first two sentinel nodes were positive, the third was negative. I know it can skip, as SpecialK had that experience. c) Had a 9% probability of additional lyphm node involvement. d) Although I had 9mm and 6mm of cancer in my lymph nodes, I had no evidence of LVI. e) I read a study published in Oct. 2010 www.medpagetoday.com/MeetingCo... which basically said "Axillary radiation therapy may control the axilla in sentinel lymph node-positive patients as effectively as complete axillary lymph node dissection, and could become an alternative treatment of the axilla for patients with positive sentinel lymph nodes". Since then additional studies have been concluded and published which discuss whether or not ALND is needed in certain cases. http://jama.ama-assn.org/content/305/6/569. Among patients with limited SLN metastatic breast cancer treated with breast conservation and systemic therapy, the use of SLND alone compared with ALND did not result in inferior survival. http://jco.ascopubs.org/content/29/34/4479.full "In conclusion, on the basis of the results of Z0011, a significant proportion of patients with one to two positive SLNs and BCS can safely forego ALND. The majority of these patients do not need to be subjected to the short-term and long-term morbidity of ALND."   So based on my pathology and the other treatments I was going to do, chemo and radiation of the axilla and supraclavical, I decided that it was not worth the risk for me to have the ALND. Everyone's situation is different. If you are unsure of the recommendations of your doctors, please go and get second or third opinions, and discuss recent studies. You need to be comfortable with the decision you make. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2011 05:38PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: TonLee - When I was reading your post, I felt like it was a partial tape recording of one of my appointments.   Although my stats are a little different, I refused the axilla dissection also and ran into the same type of comments when getting different opinions from one medical oncologist and one radiation oncologist ... "that the axilla dissection should have been done", "needed it find out the extent of the cancer spread", "would have given us more information", etc...  In fact the medical oncologists even said that they could not be sure of my staging, because it was incomplete.   I talked about it with the medical oncologist I decided to go with for my treatment and basically came to the conclusion that there are changes going on in the cancer treatment field with the "standards of care" and many doctors are not completely convinced that we should be doing these changes so quickly and that more studies need to be done with narrower populations. Thankfully my oncologist is supportive of the decision I made. With regards to scans, at my request my surgical oncologist had me do a PET/CT Scan soon after my BMX after the pathology showed positive lymph nodes because I did not want to do the ALND and needed additional information in order to make my decision.   My medical oncologist that I went with told me that she would not have recommended the scan because the odds were it would not have shown anything, because the scan usually only picks up stuff (cancerous or benign) that is more than 1 cm, and the odds were that if the cancer did get past my lymph nodes, they would be too small to be detected by the scan.  Future scans will only be needed if I had symptoms indicating that were was a problem because with the advancements in chemotherapy, and the other treatment(s) I would be doing, i.e., radiation and Tamoxifen, if heaven forbid the cancer survived, since my chemo was slow growing, it would take several years to show up in a scan.  I hope this helps.

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2011 06:34PM - edited Apr 21, 2011 06:42PM by ProudMom_Wife I too had a MX to avoid Rads.  In fact I had a BMX primarily because of family history and to be even.  So when I ended up having 2 positive SN, I was surprised that I might need Rads, even though 2 other nodes were clear.  I fell into the 'grey' area.  And I asked the same question, if you want to radiate the lymph nodes, why surgically remove more, especially since all tests, including a PET/CT Scan I had after the BMX came back clear?  That would increase my changes for LE.  Thankfully my surgical oncologist, the medical oncologist I went to for consultation only and then the medical oncologist I went to for treatment all agreed with my decision to skip the ALND if I understood that radiation of the lymph nodes needed to seriously be considered.  The problem I ran into was finding a RO who would respect my decision to not radiate my chest wall, since the pathology didn't support radiating the chest wall.  It was just the 'standard of care'. Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2011 01:03PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: TonLee - just got back from seeing my RO again.  Asked about the thyroid.  He said that there is nothing to use, i.e., like a shield to protect it.  He said because of how he plans to direct the radiation it was not going to be near my thyroid, but that does not guarantee that the thyroid might not get 'scatter' radiation from the beam.  He also went on to say he has never had any patients who have developed hypothyroidism from the treatment that he is aware of, and that since I have shown no signs of ever having thyroid issues I should not worry about it.  He agrees though that it is a good idea to have the thyroid checked on a yearly basis after treatment.  So this is something I need to put on my list of yearly tests to have run with my primary doctor. We also talked about the carotid artery.  He said there was not way to avoid it with the supraclavical radiation.  So 20-30+ yrs down the road I may develop a problem which could increase the risk for a stroke.  But then again, maybe not.  Then he once again brought up radiating my chest wall since he discussed my case with additional colleagues, and once again I said no.  He said he would be remiss in his duties if he did not try to persuade me.  But he said it is my body, my cancer, no two cancers are the same, everyone responds differently to treatment and it is utilimately my choice and he supports my decision.  He might keep trying to talk me into it, but at least he is also supporting me.  I guess this means he cares which is a good thing.

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2011 08:46PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: slcst12 - YES!!!!! - for me the first round of Taxol has been soooo much easier than AC.  I am actually beginning to feel like myself more.  The only issues I have had so far, and remember I have only had one round of DD Taxol, having an rash, actually maybe two rashes.  The first rash I have gotten on Day 10 after infusion with AC, but this time with Taxol I got it I think Day 4.  So my MO thinks it is a reaction to Neulasta and appeared sooner because I am not taking steroids now. The second rash only appeared on my hands and it was like a bunch little blisters, but I started taking Benadryl and that ended up clearing both up.  Yes my fingers were peeling really bad as I finished up with AC.  I started using Coconut Oil and it has worked much better than any of the lotions I was trying before.   With Taxol I did get some joint and muscle pain and ended up taking Vicodin, but only 4 total, so it was manageable.  No issues with my intestines per se, although I think they are still recovering from AC.  I actually have an appetite and I think I have gained some weight.  My eyes are also not bothering as much.  Every day they seem to get better.  No signs of neuropathy so far.   I upped the L-Glutamine to 15g 2x/day, but kept everything the same with the rest of my supplements.  I also am going for acupuncture two days before my infusion.   So in a nutshell, so far Taxol has been much better than AC.  I am praying it stays that way for the remaining 3 treatments.  Hope your treatment go well.

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2011 06:49PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: moe0279 - AC was much more difficult for me than Taxol has been.  I did AC first.  I had major mood swings, crying, depression, feeling totally overwhelmed, etc....  I ended up having to stop work and go on disability, and that really helped to ease my stress levels.  I also had major problems with sleeping, I felt like a moody crying walking zombie most of the time.  I think a lot of this was because of the steriods.   No real suggestions on food, eat whatever you can stomach, you might want to stay away from spicy foods.  I drank lots of green tea or ginger tea, and water with lemon in it.  I also did a lot of crying over the fact that I felt that I was letting my family down because I was a mess.  But the support from this forum, stopping work and talking with my oncologist finally got me to realize that this was short term and soon things would get better, and they have.  It is tough, but you can do it.  What is it that folks say about chemo "it's doable".  It is, but that doesn't mean it doesn't suck. I did have a reaction to the Neulasta shot, broke out in a rash.  I am still taking it though am trying to control it with Claritin now, if that doesn't work I will use Benadryl again, since I know it works, but it makes me really drowsy. My boys are older (18 & 16), so they are pretty self sufficient.  The hardest part for them was when I went through the BMX.  They have adjusted to the chemo treatments and are really supportative and as understanding as they can be under the circumstances.  My husband is really supportative, but he stressed too.  Thankfully lots of friends and family have been helping with meals and driving me for appointments, etc... which has helped us out and make them all feel better that they are helping us too, which they really are. Definitely drink lots of fluids!!!!  Good luck and let us know how we can support you.  You will make it through.

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2011 08:39AM ProudMom_Wife wrote: AimeeMac - Wow!  5mg or did you mean 0.5mg?  I was given a 1mg prescription, which states that I can take 1mg every six hours.  A friend who is a nurse suggested that I try the method described above, about cutting the 1mg in half and staggerring them, and it worked.  Lately I can sleep until around 5:30am, and then if I just lay in bed for about half an hour, I end up falling asleep again until around 8:30am, and that is with a total of 1mg Ativan for the entire night.  For me, that is progress.  But if I wake up around 2-3am and can't get back to sleep, then I take another 0.5mg. Every so often when having a bad day and I just knew I would have problems sleeping (usually infusion days) I would not cut the pills but take 1mg at around 6pm planning on another one around midnight.  Sometimes I would not fall asleep and just read or watched TV, but it would relax me, and then when would take another 1mg at midnight and would fall asleep within 20 minutes.  As I said, I really hate having to take medication in order to sleep.  I try every so often to skip it, sometimes I can.  Once all these treatments are done my oncologist said she will work with me to ween off of them and I will also be looking into natural remedies to help me with it too.  Hope this helps.

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2010 09:31PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: Hi Vis0121 - I think the expansion during chemo is up to the PS and your particular circumstances.  My PS said he will expand me depending upon how I am feeling.  His main objective is to have me expanded and ready for the exchange surgery before I start radiation, if I do radiation.  He doesn't want to expand me after radiation in case I do it.  I probably will do radiation.  Just need to talk to a few radiologist first.  I am concerned about radiating my left axilla because I fall into the grey area on whether or not it is beneficial.  So if I know 100% that I wasn't doing radiation then he would go even slower with expansion, possibly waiting until chemo was done. I know how you must feel to think that you won't have chemo at the time of your BMX.  I was clinically node negative, then surprise, 2/4 positive when the final pathology came back.  So now chemo and possible radiation all because of those two little positive nodes. My Onc said my hair will start to grow back not that long after I finished the AC part and start on the Taxol, just as my eyebrows and eyelashes start to fall out.  Oh joy.  But different chemicals do different things. I really hate that we are all having to go threw this, but one thing I have learned on this journey so far is how strong the woman on this site are.  Although I am scared beyond belief, I know that I can do it.  When I get down, all I need to do is read some of the wonderful postings to get some strength to face what is next.   I am so honestly grateful for this website and all the brave women who are kind enough to share their experiences, knowledge and information to help others as they battle to really crappy disease.

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2011 09:42AM ProudMom_Wife wrote: amyK - Don't quit.  My chemo is DD AC + DD T. I had a real tough 2nd round, the 3rd round went better until this week.  I think my RBCs have dropped.  I am feeling like crap, get dizzy everytime I get up and am now worried that I am anemic (have a history of it) and think they might not infuse me next week for my 4th round because of it.  Part of me is thinking that would be wonderful not to have a 4th round.  Then I talk to my cousin, who was dx at age 36.  She is now 56, a twenty year survivor, and I ask her to share with me again whe she had to go through to beat the cancer (I have done this several times when I felt like quitting).  Back then they did not control the SEs the way they do now.  I then realize how thankful I am for the advancements in treatment, although they are still barbaric, and that I will be a survivor just like her.  Then I realize that I can do it to be around for another 20+ years and see my kids grown, with their own families and me enjoying retirement years with my DH. My cousin has advised me to have a friend or famiy member who makes me laugh come and visit me when I am feeling like crap, to watch a movie, site outside in the sun, talk a short walk, etc... just not be alone when I am wanting to quit.  To vent to someone, vent to these boards as you are, just let it all out. Talk with your oncologist.  Don't quit.  I know it is tough.  You are almost done with AC.  We are here for you.  If you want to PM please do, since we appear to be on the same treatement/schedule.  AC really sucks, I know, but you can do it.

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2011 09:11AM ProudMom_Wife wrote: moe0279 - My onc. nurse told me that I could experiencee bone pain up to 1 week or 10 days after the shot. I did experience bone pain in my sternum about 8 days after the shot once. She said everyone is different and sometimes your body may react a little differently from treatment to treatment. Hope this helps. yorleh - Welcome and we are here for you. jogshuttle - My oncologist said it was not uncommon for liver enzymes to spike when going from AC to Taxol. So she wanted to see if by reducing it by 20% if that would improve it. She said the 20% reduction was still in the acceptable range for effective treatment for a person of my size and weight. When I got home I searched the web to see if the L-Glutamine would have effected the liver and found that in rare cases too much L-Glutamine could effect liver enzymes. I forgot to mention to her that I had upped the L-Glutamine and forgot about it when I had the appointment - bad me. So I emailed her about it and she wanted me to bumped it back down to where I was before. But I was so afraid of neuropathy, that I did a gradual decline of it. I went down to 20g for a few days, then down to 15g/day and now I am back down to about 10g/day. No signs of neuropathy. My last blood test showed two of the liver enzymes are now back in the normal range and the third one is just slightly elevated. So my onc. did not increase the DD Taxol for round three and I am sticking with 10g/day. We did not discuss what would happen if the liver enzymes did not go down, didn't want to think about it unless I had to I guess. jcoutee - A mastectomeny is a personal decision, when you have the choice, and you are young. I chose a BMX because of my family history even though I am BCRA neg., plus I was 45 at time of dx and I was done with having kids, and in all honestly, mine were floppy and droopy, so I decided to remove the stress and hope to be smaller and perkier when the treatments were over. I was also hoping to avoid radiation, but that didn't happen in my case, I will be having radiation to my lymph nodes soon. If you decide to go that route, just remember if you get implants (either silicone or saline) they need to be replaced about every 10 years. Also, find out the type of follow up you would receive to check for a recurrance or new breast cancer if you have a MX. There seems to be no "standard" for this. You might not be comfortable with how they plan to follow up with you through the years if you go the MX route.

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2011 01:06PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: WarriorPrincess24 - I just finished DD Taxol on Wed.  I did not have problems with neuropathy, but do have hot flashes (am officially in chemopause). Don't know if this will help or not, but since I started chemo back in January I have been taking 50mg of B6 and B12 twice a day, along with L-Glutamine powder (5mg twice a day also).  I did take more of the L-Glutamine when I started the Taxol regime because I was so afraid of neuropathy, but had issues with high liver enzymes so I decreased it.  I also do acupuncture every two weeks.  I will continue with this for several months because I read that Taxol can still effect you several months after finishing and my oncologist said that it was fine, just need to clear it with the RO.  I think the acupuncture really helped me with the hot flashes, still get them, but they have not as bad.  It might have also helped with the neuropathy. I never did the ice bags during transfusion as UTMom suggested, but I have heard from several people that it really helped them.  So definitely give it a try with your next infusion.  Also with Taxol I took Vicodin on days 3-5 because of joint pains.  Am on it now since it is day 4 for me, hopefully I am making sense with what I am writing since I am under the influence  . Good luck and I am sending you {{{HUGS}}}

Posts.Content: May 8, 2011 08:28PM - edited May 8, 2011 08:35PM by ProudMom_Wife christine47 - Thank you, and it is so cool that your DH and boys sent you roses.  Roses are my favorite. bdavis - I hope your last treatment goes well and you feel fine for your trip.  I will be thinking of you. WarriorrPrincess24 - Sorry you are having such a difficult time with neuropathy.  Have you talked to your doctor about whether you can switch to another type of chemo, perhaps Abraxane, or another one, or are you too far along for this to occur?  Can he reduce the dosage to help with the SEs?  My understanding about Abraxane is that it causes less SEs than Taxol, and although it may cause neuropathy it is suppose not be as harsh. I personally know a couple of people who have had discussions with their oncologists to stop chemo early because of side-effects.  They discussed the impact it would have on the prognosis before they made the decision to stop.  Two ended up continuing with their treatments but at lower doses, the third stopped chemo treatments.  Thankfully all three are healthy at this time, although none has hit the five year mark yet, but I am hopeful for all of them.  It is a personal decison based on your pathology and discussion with your oncologist.   I hope others have more information to share with you. Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2011 10:00AM ProudMom_Wife wrote: WarriorPrincess - I agreee with JulieH's advise and check with your ob/gyn and onc to understand the best birth control method with your ER/PR status even if your ovaries haven't completed rejuventated it. For me at 46 I think my ovaries are permanently shut down, and I personally could not be happier.  I am done with having kids.  My OB/GYN says he will monitor my hormone level closely over the next 5 years and if there is any sign that they are coming back, then they will be removed when I am done with tamoxifen before moving to an AI.  Like christine47, I will also be having my uterus and ovaries watched closely. JulieH - I heard the same thing about the lashes and brows needing to be re-programmed.   MaryMeg - For my skin I have been using Miaderm, which I purchased over the internet.  I know some folks have said that 100% aloe vera (no alcohol in it) works great too (it just never worked all that great for me on those few occassions when I would get a sunburn, probably because it had alcohol in it), so I decided to use as a backup if needed, but haven't needed too.  Also I am drinking turmeric tea (some folks take curcumin - a think there is actually a trail or study being done curcumin helping skin during rads), and also staying well hydrated and eating avacados (or yummy homemade guacamole).  Disclaimer:  Only the skin from the side of my neck over to my axilla, both front and back are being effective by my rad treatment, so I am not haveing to deal with other issues with breast/chest wall radition, so this could be why what I am using/doing appears to work well for me.   tsundermann - cool more than halfway through rads.  I actually enjoy going to my rads treatment, not to be zapped, but because I met this wonderful woman who is also going through it right before me and we have great talks and work on a puzzle in the waiting room.  Glad to see you are more than half way through.  It great to get over that half way mark. I went to see my Physical Therapist/LE Specialist yesterday because I was having shooting pain in my left arm from my axilla to my wrist.  Started around the end of the send week of rads, but only in the mornings.  She said I show no signs of LE (yippy!) and the pain was due to a nerve, which could have been triggered by rads or from one of the surgeries.  I am to keep wearing my compression sleeves as instructed and she taught me a few new stretches and had to properly do a manual lymph massage.  She also taught me a better way to massage my saline implants to get the soft and moveable - DH gets to help with this  Got two more rad txs done, only 5 left.  Will get my blood drawn on Monday and get zapped before the results come in, just in case.  RO said as long as the count is stabile or continues to go up he will continue with treatments.  Keeping my fingers crossed.

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2011 08:41AM ProudMom_Wife wrote: Hi everyone, Just thought I would see how folks are doing.  Hair is growing back, might actually keep it short though, it is easy to take care of, except my head, neck and ears get cold easily.  Shaving legs once a week, although it is still patchy, go figure.  Eyebrows and eyelashes are back in. Inplants are settling in, although I am lopsided.  If the right side (non-cancer side) does not drop in the next few months need to decide whether or not to have it 'fixed'.  Can't tell if I wear a bra, but I don't want to have to wear a bra all the time.  Exercising, although I know I need to do more, I am trying to slowly build it up, because I don't want to over do it again. bdavis - I hope the wound is healing and you are not having any more complications. I was just wondering, for those of you who have completed all the invasive treatments, i.e., surgery, chemo and/or rads, how are you feeling about the future? Most days I am sooo hopeful, believing that the surgery removed all cancer, and if any little micro sized cancers escaped that the chemo and rads got it.  And if it tries to re-establish itself the Tamoxifen will starve it.  Other days I think that I just need to get to 10 years NED (since I am ER+/PR+) and then if it were to recur that medical advances will have occured and it would be caught really early and the new treatments will eliminate it for good.  I try to be hopeful all the time, but there are days and times when I just plain out worry.  I guess the important thing is my attitude on life has changed a bit and I am not stressing over the little stuff and am doing my best to enjoy all the time I can with family and friends, and not putting off stuff that I have put off for years. Think of all of you daily and really hoping everyone is doing great.

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2013 05:15PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: Hi everyone, It has been two years now since we all met on the chemo portion of our cancer journey.  I hope everyone is doing great and life is getting back to 'normal', although I know it is a new normal for all of us. JulieH - I hope your DH is doing well with his treatments and is in remission. I am still NED, yippy!, but still have checks every three months.  No scans, just physical checks and blood work (no tumor markers though).  Chemo brain is still around for me too MaryMeg, but it has gotten better, hopefully it will continue to improve.  It is definitely worse when I get tired. Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2011 07:50AM - edited Jan 4, 2011 04:51PM by ProudMom_Wife Welcome everyone to the "club no wants to join" moe0279 - I was told to try Glutamine powder, which you can buy at health food stores for around $20/bottle.  You put 1 tsp in 8oz of water, swish around in your mouth for about 30 sec, then swollow.  Do this twice a day.  I have not done this yet, but will start it tomorrow and see if it helps. suz3 - I am ER+/PR+ HER- with 2 positive nodes (there could be more, but since there was only a 9% probability of it I declined to have an axilla dissection).  I went to 3 oncs and got three different protocols. I went back to all of them and asked their opinon of what the others recommended and then did my own research.  The three were TC, AC+T and TAC.  Although there are studies for TC vs AC there wasn't enough information on TC vs AC+T.  Basically they all said AC+T would work just as well for me, it just carried the additional, yet small risk of heart issues down the road.  Based on my particular situation and health I chose DD AC+T and am doing what I can to prevent the SE which could impact my heart, etc...  plus since my nodes situation was a bit unknown I decided to be more aggressive otherswise I would have gone with TC. Anniemomofthree - good luch with the Cold Cap!!  Interested to know if it works, have heard mixed results. MarMeg - I love New Zealand!!! Spend 2 1/2 wondeful weeks there about 7 years ago and did not want to leave. Hugs to everyone as we start this new phase.  Edited to correct dosage on Glutamine, it should be 1 teaspoon.

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2011 05:02PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: Hi all, Just wanted to provide additional information I got today on the L-Glutamine Power.  The difference in amounts depends on the concentration you buy.  So here is what I got from a chemo nurse today.  Take 15 grams mixed in warm water, swish in your mouth for 30 seconds then swallow.  Do this twice a day.  Begin on the first day of chemo for a total of 7 days.  After your last treatment do this for a total of 14 days.  If you have any kidney or liver issues/problems decrease the amount of grams to 5 or 10 grams for each treatment.   I am not a doctor, nor endorse the use of this product, I am just passing along the information. Hope it helps some of you.  JulieH - I am not doing Claritin at this time, I wanted to see if the vitamins and supplements I am taking, with the OK of my onc, works.  If not, then I will try the Claritin with the next round.  I was also told to take Tylenol 30 minutes before I get the shot, then every 6 hours as needed.  No motrin or aleve.  If I have problems then I am suppose to call to get something stronger like Vicodin.

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2011 10:04AM ProudMom_Wife wrote: Here is what I am taking, with the approval of my oncologist.  Everyone is different.  My treatment is DD AC followed by T. CoQ10 - 100mg a day (helps protect heart beause of Adriamycin) B6/B12 - 50 mg three times a day (suppose to help with Neuropathy and chemo brain) Calcium + Magnesium + Vitamin D3 - two times a day Multivitamin ( only on days 6 - 12) L-Glutamine Powder (15 mg, mix w/warm water, swish, then swallow) two times a day.  (Suppose to help with mouth sores and neuropathy) Biotene toothpaste, rinse and gel (used the get before bed) Warm salt water rinsing after ever meal. Colace + Senna (didn't work well enough, might be adding Miralax this next round, but need to clear with onc. first. Hope this helps.  I really hate taking all this on top of the prescriptions, it gets really annoying, but I do it. Everyone seems to be doing well, keeping those good thoughts coming your way.  For those of you starting this week, the anticipation is the worse.  Just follow your instructions and if you have questions ask.  Don't be afraid to call your doctor/cancer center with questions.

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 01:56PM - edited Feb 3, 2011 01:57PM by ProudMom_Wife Happy Birthday MaryMeg !!!  I agree, you could not let those brownies be wasted.   I am on day 2 of my 3rd tx of AC and so far it is going so much better than last time.  I think now that I am on disability and not working the removal of the stress has helped, hopefully it continues this way. The positives I have found so far, reconnecting with friends and family.  We are all so busy, but because of this damn crappy cancer we are all connecting more.  I have learned to have more patience, this is a biggy for me.  Still need to work on it more, but I am definitely making improvements on it.  I don't let what others think bother me as much, there are more important things in life now.  I actually went commando with my bald head and it felt great.  I don't care if people stare.  I have cancer damn it and I am going to beat it, if you don't like my bald head then don't stare.  Also planning for the future is no longer only for saving up for 10-20 years down the road, which we still do, but not as much, but we are making plans to enjoy more things as a family and as a couple now, even if it means just grabbing the tent and taking off for weekend (when the weather is better).    To those asking about alcohol -  my onc said one drink once or twice a week during the down time between chemo treatments was OK.  I did try a few sips of beer, but just didn't taste good, so I had DH finish it.  Tried red wine also, and that just didn't taste good either.  So I decided to just stay away from the alcohol.  Everyone is different though. Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2011 03:13PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: Hi everyone,  Hope everyone is doing well.  Looks like progress is being made.  Yay! For those of you doing DD Taxol I just got back from my doctor appointment and tomorrow will be my infusion.  Basically this is her approach, every oncologist may do a different variation.  The will start me with pre-meds of Benedryl, Decatron, Zofran and an antacid (can't rememer which one).  Then they give me a small dose of the Taxol and watch me for a reaction for about 45 minutes.  If all goes well then they will proceed with the rest of the Taxol.  If I have a reaction, then the will deal with it and she will be seeing sooner than planned. There are no prescriptions for me to take this time.  If I have a problem with nausea, since I still have a few meds left from the first phase, she said I could take Zofran, Compazine (which I never used), or Ativan.   But she said most of her patients don't need any nausea medication.  If I end of needing it, then I am to also call her. She said the major side effect I might experience is bone/joint pain.  If so, I can start with Tylenol, if it doesn't work, I am to call her and she will get me a prescription for something stronger.  She said some patients still get a little constipated, so I should continue to drink Smooth Ease Tea if needed.  She says the constipation usually isn't as bad since her patients usually don't need to take the Zofran. So I have my fingers crossed that it will go smoothly.  We will see and I will let you know. Good luck to everyone.  Oh - Loved the dancing boots and the dance video too.  You ladies are wonderful.

Done with all of those treatments.  Congratulations!  I can understand how you would be anxious with your first post-diagnosis mammogram.  Think positive thoughts.  I am impressed that they are having you do a mammogram already.  Sounds like you have a good doctor who will provide you with great follow up care.  You are fortunate, some doctors will tell their patients to call them if something pops up and just ignore follow ups.  Seriously I have met some of these patients who just don't know what to do after they finish treatment. I had a BMX, so no more mammograms for me.  My onc. said once I am done with rads then I will get into a routine of being checked every three months with a physical exam and blood work.  In the meantime as I am learning to massage my implants, I am  to become more familiar with them in case something develops.  If I show any symptoms, etc... then I will have an MRI or other appropriate scan(s).   As time goes on and if things are fine, then the appointments go to 6 month intervals for oncology appts.  Intertwined with be yearly physicals w/pap smears, UltraSounds for my uterus (going on tamoxifen), etc...  Onc says I will be closely monitored even though no mammograms.  Thankfully all my doctors know and work with each other very well and they all said they will be in contact with each other as I see each one of them. Good luck with your mammogram tomorrow.  Sending {{HUGS}}.  Let us know how it goes.

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2011 10:12AM - edited Mar 18, 2011 10:13AM by ProudMom_Wife slcst12 - for the L-glutamine I think I started at about 10g a day.  One teaspoon is about 5g.  So I had some twice a day.  That's what I did when I started with A/C.  Then bumped it up when I started Taxol on the advise of others (not my onc), and I think it affected my liver enzymes being high.  So my onc said to lower it back down.  So I went to 20g for the day and all seems to be OK with me now.  Everyone is different though.  A friend of mine who is on a different chemo regime for colon cancer takes 15g/day for neuropathy and has no issues.  There are not many, if any real side effects with L-glutamine, but on those rare occassions, there could be, so definitely start with small amounts.   I have had no signs of neuropathy and when I took the Neulasta shot through A/C and one Taxol the only time I felt bone pain was when I skipped the L-glutamine.  Hope this helps.

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2011 08:05PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: tsundermann - I have been making slow changes, but need to make more to my diet.  I haven't been as good as I should with the changes that I need to make, but my oncologist told me to just go slow and steady with the changes.  Plus she was worried about my weight.  I had lost about 11 lbs. in the 9 month period preceeding my diagnosis, just because I needed to, mainly through exercise.  But since then I have lost another 13 lbs. (not really through exercise) and my doctor wants me to stabilize my weight and not loose any more.  In fact she would like me to gain at least 5 more pounds (in muscle preferrably).    I have basically given up coffee and alcohol.  I am only drinking green tea, ginger tea, tumeric tea, juice and water with lemon.  I now make myself fruit smoothies about 4-5 times a week and am eating more veggies and fruits throughout the day and with meals, making sure to have yogurt daily, and am paying attention to food labels and trying to eat healthy.  Oh, I am also eating fish, which I don't like, about once every 2 weeks.   I am exercising more, but still need to do more.  I have a recombinant bike and my goal is to do at least 20 miles a week, and do Pilates at home with a DVD about twice a week.  Although it is hard to do on those chemo weeks, so sometimes I fall a little short, but if I can't do all of it, I try to at least do some of it.  Once chemo ends I plan on signing up for Yoga and doing more outdoor stuff, like walking and hiking again. I am taking supplements, but what I take with be altered as I end chemo, start radiation, and then again when I start tamoxifen.  So I am making slow changes, but still have a ways to go, but feel like I am heading in the right direction.

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2011 05:00PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: bdavis - have a wonderfule trip! tsundermann - my Onc explained to me today that many times oncologist think that women in the 40s whose periods stop during chemo will probably stay in menapause, therefore they put them on an AI instead of Tamoxifen.  However, my oncologist said they are finding that sometimes these women's ovaries are not shut down completely, just enough so they no longer bleed, but actually they are not in menapause, therefore the AI is not working correctly and not blocking the estrogen.  Because of this she says I need to go on Tamoxifen because it works on both pre-menapausal and post-menapausal women, and I am only only 45.  Also as a side note, I have not bled in over 6 years because I had a uterine ablation (in my opinion one of the greatest inventions in the world is the Novasure procedure), but I still ovulated, at least until I started chemo.  Please ask your doctor about this since you are not even 40 yet.  I don't know of any studies to link to, but wanted to share this. JulieH - thanks for the info on the hand/foot syndrome, my onc told me the same thing today, that I had that along with my other rash, so the benadryl only worked on one, and the other just cleared up around the same time.  Mine was a late reaction to the AC and she said should not reappear with Taxol.  Got my labs back, my liver enzymes are high, so my Taxol is being reduced by 20% and my oncologist wanted me to decrease the L-Glutamine just in case it was effecting my liver.  So I am going to 10mg/ 2x day now.  Also my White Blood Count was high, so she wants me to skip the Neulasta shot - maybe I won't get a rash again.  I guess this is one way to find out if my other rash was a reaction to the shot or not. So I get my second Taxol tomorrow and then only 2 more left.  I can hardly wait.   You women have also inspired me to plan a nice family vacation this summer to Hawaii after I am done with RADS.  Thank you.

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2011 08:12AM ProudMom_Wife wrote: hsgray - Ouch!  So sorry about all those needle pokes.  You might want to consider a port, especially if you are getting Adriamycin.  I didn't want a port, but my onc strongly recommended it for this particular treatment. slct12- Just learned yesterday that sugar free lemon drops, or drinking room temperature water with lemon can help with nausea also.  Give that child of yours extra {{HUGS}} from your chemo gals. UTMom2014 - Glad you are home, so sorry you had to go through that.  Hope you are feeling much better now. AliT - Yes, I give myself the Neulasta shot, so far I have not had any problems and have done it twice now, knock on wood.  I am not taking Claritin, although that seems to help with lots of folks.  I am taking a combination on supplements/alternatives which were approved by my onc, which may be working, specifically L-Glutamine Power and B6/B12 vitamins.  Unless I have problems I am not going to stop to find out if it really is what is working, I am not that brave.  With the Dexamethasone I was told to drink lots of fluids and to be sure to take it with food.  So I am drinking lots of tea and water with lemon juice. Amara - Sorry for your diagnosis.  These boards are filled with lots of information and helpful hints.  Be sure you understand all your test/pathology reports and get copies of them.  And feel free to get two or three opinions.  It is worth the extra money if your insurance won't pay, it has helped me to be more comfortable with the decisions I have made for my particular case.  I believe most if not all of the chemo protocols for breast cancer result in losing most if not all of your hair.  It will grow back though.  If you are HER2+ chemo will be highly recommended because it is fast growing and you want to knock it out ASAP.  I have met many ladies you have done chemo before surgery who were HER2+ who responded exceptionally well to the chemo and their tumors were reduced significantly.  Good luck we will be thinking of you and sending good thoughts your way. JulieH - As always you are amazing and an inspiration.

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2011 08:39PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: christine47 and slcst12 - CONGRATS, it's HAPPY DANCE time!!!! UTMom2014 - Hang in there and feel free to vent.  We are here for you! baf4294 - Great outlook, thank you for sharing. yorelh - I hope your son is doing better and you do not get sick. tsundermann -  Had my exchange and port removed Monday.  Absolutely love that my port is gone.  The exchange surgery was easier than the BMX, however a little bit tougher than I imagined,.  I thought it would have been easier, but then my DH pointed out to me that I had the exchange only 10 days after my last infusion and my body probably had not fully recovered from the last round of SEs (not to mention a couple of months of chemo) before this surgery.  So that is probably why it was not as easy as I thought it would be, also I always have issues with anestesia.  Don't get me wrong, it was definitely easier than the BMX and not as painful, I think I had more pain honestly from the removal of the port.  I haven't taken any pain meds since yesterday morning.  Today (Friday) I also went for my Rads appt. and got two tattoos and had to put my arm over my head for mapping.  Originally I had it scheduled on Wed., but I rescheduled because I wasn't doing as good as I had hoped and I didn't think I could move and keep my arm over my head for an extended period of time.  I was able to do so today, but had to have the technician help me to move my arm back down twice because it was hurting keeping it over my head for too long and I could not move it down on my own.  So I am glad I got those extra days between the exchange and the Rads appointment.  I did have full range of motion before the exchange surgery, I just think my body needed more time to heal because it was too close to the end of chemo for me.  Hope this helps. Hope everyone has a wonderful weekend.

Posts.Content: May 3, 2011 03:53PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: Hi everyone, my internet has been intermittent for the last few days so I haven't been on much.   My last Taxol, three weeks ago, was the toughest Taxol tx to get over for me. Just like some of you have said, meantally I was great, but physically it took longer, and then it didn't help that I had the exchange so soon after.   I was anemic and had elevated liver enzymes (again) right before surgery, but they went ahead with the surgery because my WBC and Platets were OK. Of course I became more anemic and had issues last week with my temperature going up, but never over 100, and not feeling good generally. Melanie_Anne - Hair, hmmm.  The existing hair on my head which did not fall out has grown a tiny bit, but I don't think any new hair on my head has sprouted yet. Hope you feel better with the new meds. JulieH - I will be starting rads on May 16. The tattoos were not bad. Got two of them. Did not feel one, the other one hurt like a really sharp pinch and the pain lasted for about a minute. Honestly though I do not understand why people would get a tattoo for fun. Just the thought of having the pinch over and over again in order to make a design does not sit well with me.  When I was younger I thought about getting one, so glad I never did.  I would have been a wimp and stopped the process without it being completed.  Wouldn't that have turned out pretty? JeanH - Yippy, one more to go, the end is near. moe0279 - That 3rd AC was the toughest for me too, and I know others in our group have said the same thing, and my oncologist told me for most of her patients, the 3rd AC is the toughest.  I had to start taking 1mg of Ativan every night I think after the second AC treatment and still take it every night. Talk with your onc and see if they can make any changes to your meds to help you through it.  You are almost done. You can do it.  Sending you {{{HUGS}}}.

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2011 08:59AM ProudMom_Wife wrote: Hope everyone had a nice July 4th weekend. I have been out of town with no internet, which was kind of nice. Went up to Lake Tahoa, wore my compression sleeves for the change in elevation, had no problems. Started Tamoxifen too, and so far so good. UTMom2014 - Hang in there, you are almost done with chemo.   Sorry about tooth issues. I had a fake tooth (cap) pop out during chemo. My MO said as long as the dental work was not done during my NADIR time it was OK. My dentist was great and came in over a weekend for me to fix it. What a great guy. tsundermann - Yep I am in chemo pause too and hoping those ovaries are shut down for good. My MO said for about 50% of woman in their mid-40s their ovaries stay shut down. However for the other 50% the ovaries can restart, even with low levels of estrogen. That's what you need to watch for. Because 5 years down when you are done with Tamoxifen if your ovaries start producing estrogen, even at low levels, if you are switched to an AI, it won't be effective on the estrogen produced by your ovaries. So you need to keep monitoring your estrogen levels. I might end up taking my ovaries out at that point. It is a wait and see approach, because they might say it is OK to take Tamoxifen for longer periods of time by then also. JeanH - My DH loves to rub my head because the hair it is soo soft. My hot flashes haven been tolerable. Started during chemo and have gotten a little bit more frequent with Tamoxifen, but so far manageable, although I just started last Friday with Tamoxifen. Knock on wood, hopefully it won't get bad. My hot flahes arrive like clock work though, start around 5pm, come in waves. But during the day nothing. Kind of wierd, but I will take it. bdavis - My eyebrows came roaring back. I was going to pluck them and my DH is begging me not too. He says I look cute with my soft fuzzy hair and dark, thicker eyebrows. So I will refrain for a while. Figured he has had to deal with quite a bit with all of this, so I make him happy with not plucking for a while. JulieH - Glad your skin has held up well during rads. Yeah, two more to go. Actually you are probably down to one as I type this. Tomorrow you will feel great, because one more phase of your treatment will be over. I started restorative yoga too (had to stop because of my neutrophil levels being low), but I really liked it and plan on starting up again once my levels have returned. Oh yeah, even though I finished rads a week and a half ago, I went for my lab work last Wed. and my Neutrophils had tanked to 900 again. Yep Neutropenia for me, so I stayed away from people up in Lake Tahoe and just relaxed on a deck reading a book. I felt great though. I think they dropped because two days after finishing rads I went with my older son to his Freshman Orientation (which was a long drive) and just did too much walking and not enough resting. Plus we did not get home until almost midnight the night before my blood test. So I get new labs drawn tomorrow and if they are good I am allowed to resume yoga again. Considering the problems I have had with my blood counts through radiation, I am so glad I was given the Neulasta shot during chemo, otherwise I don't think I would have made it through. chistine47 - How much Vitamin D have you been taking to get your levels up? My were low and I have been working to get them back up. I am taking between 2000-2500 IU a day. My MO said if my levels stay down with my next check up with her in a few weeks she might give me a prescription strenth dose. Enjoy this short work week.

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2012 11:28AM - edited Feb 18, 2012 11:48AM by ProudMom_Wife Hi pupfoster1 - I have been on Tamoxifen for about 8 months now.  My MO told me I could not take either Benadryl or Tylenol PM and gave me a URL for a more extensive list of medication to avoid.  Here is the link www.drugs.com/drug-interaction...    I was also told to avoid grapefruit and to go easy on the soy. Tamoxifen is the only one which pre-menopausal can take.  Menopausal women can take either Tamoxifen or and AI, depending on their medical history. Make sure you have both an Estradiol and FSH blood tests done to make sure you are officially in menapause.  My MO said for accuracy purposes the FSH test should be done after you have been off of Tamoxifen for at least a month because the Tamoxifen can inter with those results and you don't want to switch to an AI if you are not truly in menapause because AIs do not block estrogen produced by ovaries.

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2010 04:55PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:22AM by ProudMom_Wife Steeleamelia - It is truly a personal decision.  I am 45 and my husband told me it was my decision, he even brought up the subject of a bi-lateral mastectomy so I would not have to worry as much about a recurrance or a new cancer, even though I was already considering it, but had not shared it with him yet.  Even though I don't have the BRCA genes, I have a family history of breast cancer.  He said he would continue to love me no matter what.  He said the decision on reconstruction was my choice too.  He said if I wanted to do reconstruction, go for it now, and if I didn't like it, I can always go flat.   So I decided to have the BMX and had TEs inserted.  After finally looking at myself after surgery I thought that maybe I should not have bothered with the reconstruction.  I was originally a D cup and realized that I was actually fine without breasts, they did not define me.  But since I started the process I will continue it and if I have any issues/problems, out they come. For me, and this is just me, my life with my children and husband is more important than having breasts (which were saggy anyways).  I plan on fighting this damn disease with everything I have and if the reconstruction gets in the way, I am ready to forgo it. I chose the BMX mainly because I wanted to decrease the chances for recurrance or a new cancer.  After getting my pathology report, I know I made the correct choice for me, because 2/4 nodes were positive.  But once again, that is me, every cancer is different as each person is unique.  So look at your own circumstances and current diagnosis and know that no matter what your family and friends will continue to love you and support you on this journey.

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2012 12:47PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: ewesty - I too was in the 'grey zone'.  We have very similiar stats.  I also had a BMX, cancer on left side, with 2 positive nodes.  However I refused the ALND.  With the exception of the two positive nodes, everything else about my pathology was as good as I could hope for.  The cancer was not near my chest wall.  So I went outside the standard of care and radiated only my axilla and superclavical.   I also sought different opinions/consultations.  Everyone agreed I was in the 'grey zone' with radiation, and could go either way.  I was OK with the idea of just zapping the axilla and superclavical since I refused the ALND, but was not comfortable with rads to the chest wall.  I ended going to a radiation oncology center that works with various hospitals, cancer centers and medical oncologists Northern California, since they were willing to go outside the 'standard of care' since I didn't want the whole package. Oh the one thing I learned, at least in Northern California, a lot of the oncologists (medical, surgical, and radiation), knew each other.   If you are willing to come to California I know that UCLA, UCSF, and Stanford provide excellent consultations, and you can ask them if they have reduced rates if your insurance will not cover it. Feel free to PM me if you want. Good luck and go with your gut feeling when you make your decision. It is your body, your decision.

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2012 05:35PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: Kelley I think the wait would be beneficial for you, and I say that from experience.   All through chemo I had no problems with my blood counts, in fact I had to skip a Neulasta shot because my MO was concerned they would get too high.  After my last chemo treatment, I had one more Neulasta shot because I was having my exchange surgery 12 days after my last chemo.  I was feeling great too.  The surgery itself was much easier the the BMX, but my body had a tougher time than expected with recovery.  My blood pressure was low along with my blood counts after surgery and I was suppose to start radiation three weeks after the surgery (almost 5 weeks after last chemo).  My counts came up and I up started radiation on time.  But I had to stop radiation after about 3 1/2 weeks because my WBC and Neutrophils kept dropping.  Then they resumed radiation and almost stopped them again because my counts dropped back down.  Since I only had a few sessions left they let me continue with low counts but watched me really carefully and I had to be extremely careful about germs (in fact they told to me not go to my son's HS graduation events, although I went to them all).  I think the short time between chemo -> exchange -> rads took a toll on me.  It took 6 months after radiation was done for my WBC to get back in the normal range, but they are still at the low end.  If I could relive it - I mean actually go back in time and do it again, I would give myself at least an extra week between chemo and exchange.   I know all of us are different with how we respond to treatments and recover from surgery.  From my experience though I say as long as your Radiation Oncologist says the timing is OK, take as much time to recover from chemo and your exchange surgery before starting radiation treatments.

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2012 04:05PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: Raelan - I was in a similiar situation and I opted out of the ALND, but did chemo and rads.   My decision was based on my pathology, and also getting additional opinions from several medical and radiation oncologists. I had a 9% probability of further nodal involvement and was planning on aggressive chemo, and fell into the grey area for radiation. For me, the benefit of ALND was to see if additional nodes were involved and if the ones removed were, then they were removed (but there could still have been others left behind). It would have made no difference in the recommedation for chemo or radiation in my situation. So based on the information I had, I decided I didn't want to increase the risk of lymphedema with doing both.  I chose radiation because it was a field of radiation and not just going into there and scooping out an area. Have you seen a radiation oncologist yet? The reason I am asking is because sometimes they have a different opinion regarding the recommendation of radiation than a surgeon or medical oncologist, especially since you have LVI and some encapsulation. So a radiation oncologist may recommend rads even if you have an ALND. It is your choice and your body.  Best wishes.

The process on reconstruction was more than I had anticipated.  At first I had second thoughts about it and wondered if I should have even bothered with reconstruction.  But I am doing fine with it now that I have had my saline implants for about 6 weeks and know it was the correct decision.   Although having a MX with reconstruction is the same as BMX with reconstruction, recovering would be a little bit more difficult because you have impacted both sides with the BMX.  Both arms will be affected.  Have to sleep on your back longer too.

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2011 07:31PM - edited Jul 12, 2011 07:40PM by ProudMom_Wife I think this on-going study MA.20 Trial is important, and yes the 'standard of care' for some bc patients may be changing due to the results, but you also need to look at what the eligibility requirements were for those who partipated, because not all bc patients with 1-3 positive nodes fall into these categories.   - Must have histologically proven invasive ca of the breast w/o evidence of metastic dz. - Pts. must have been treated w/breast conservation therapy (BCT) and axillary dissection or sentinel node bx. Must be a candidate for breast XRT. - Must be at high risk of regional recurrence, due to: positive axillary nodes, or negative axillary nodes and primary tumor 2 cm or greater or primary tumor at least 5 cm or greater and less than 10 axillary nodes removed and one of the following: ER-, SBR grade 3 or lymphovascular invasion. - Sentinel node pts. are eligable if they are node negative, but still meet criteria for high risk pts. If positive sentinel nodes, must have a level I and II ALND. Edited: Thanks TonLee for that link for more details on the study, I was typing and didn't see it until after I posted.

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2014 06:21PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: Hi paloverde, I did ddAC + ddT. My job requires logical thinking (software designer) and lots of computer work. I had a really tough time with the ddAC portion of the regimen and had to go out on medical leave, I think mainly because I didn't get enough sleep/rest (if lucky about 4 hours a day). Once I stopped working and started taking meds to help me sleep life improved and I thought I could go back to work during the Taxol portion, but my MO wanted me to stay out, so I did. I had issues related to concentration, couldn't remember words when communicating with others, forgot things easily, got irritable because I knew I was wasn't communicating like I should be. What I think helped me was playing lots of brain games, even if I lost or they took my longer to do (scrabble, suduko, chess, etc...), reading (even if I had to take notes to remember what I just read), keeping a journal, leaving post-its all over and setting my alarm so I would not forget things, and exercise/yoga. Things improved over time and when I went back to work I still wasn't back to where I was before but could function and produce good work, although it took me longer than before. Now I am 2.5 years out from finishing chemo and I don't see any impact on my work (and neither does my employer - good reviews). I still think I experience minor effects from chemo, but only my DH notices them now, then again maybe it is just because I am getting older and I just want to blame it on chemo brain.

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2011 09:48AM ProudMom_Wife wrote: mary625 - I got a total of three opinions from medical oncologists after I had my surgery and the final pathology report was complete. One from the cancer center I was going to (an hour away), where my primary physician and surgical oncologist are located, one from an oncologist who was a closer to home, and then another one who was several hours away, that I refer to as an independent consult who had excellent credentials. Start doing your homework on who would like to get opinons from now, contact them and tell them of your situation, what you would like to consult with the doctor about (and if you might be wanting the doctor to treat you), and what type of information they need (definitely a pathology report and any other test results), how far in advance they need you to schedule an appointment, and then you can plan accordingly. If you question the findings of the biopsy, you can request that the slides be sent out to another lab. If your doctors want you to have therapy (chemo and/or rads) before surgery and you are not comfortable with that, definitely get additional opinions with the findings of your tests so far. This is the worst part of the journey, not knowing all the information on what exactly you need to do to fight this crappy cancer. Once you know what you are facing, get a treatment plan in place, it really allows you to just concentrate on winning the fight. This website/forums are very helpful and the folks here are very supportative. Best of luck to you. We are here to support you.

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2011 04:09PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: I had issues with high liver enzymes when I got to the DD Taxol part of chemo (DD AC + T).  My MO reduced the amount of Taxol I was given.  Was told to stay away from Tylenol.  Drink lots of green tea, water with lemon, eat healthy, etc.... and get lots of rest.  I also went for acunpuncture treatments.  My MO said if they stayed high we would re-evaluate treatment.  Thankfully that did not happen.  After the reduced Taxol my enzymes went back down to the normal range and stayed there through the remaining chemo treatments.  But after my last chemo treatment the liver enzymes shot up again.  They are now in the normal range and my liver appears to be happy again.

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2011 12:36PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: Thank you PlantLover for this thread.  When I was first dx, the initial pathology was Stage 1 with no lymph node involvement.  I opted for MX because of family history, although BRCA neg.  When final pathology came back with 2 positive lymph nodes I was devistated.  I had more cancer in my lymph nodes than in my IDC breast tumor and had no LVI.  My surgical oncologist said chemo would be recommended.  After a sleepless night I thought about all my relatives (and there have been 5) who have battled breast cancer, and came to the realization that all who did chemo were the ones who did not die of breast cancer, or are/were still alive 20+ years after dx.  I am the first of my generation to have bc.  So with my genetic makeup I feel very comfortable that I did chemo, and feel that it gave me the best odds of living a long happy life.     Everyone one of us is different, as are our cancers.  Although for best practices/studies, we have to be grouped.  What works great for one person may not work for the next person who has "identical" staging characteristics due to their genetic makeup, lifestyle, environmental factors, etc...  No one can say for certainty what will or will not work.  That is why each of us has to be our own advocate for our health and make decisions with consulation with experts in the field of what will work best for us, be it conventional, alternative or integrative. I am grateful that the doctors I met with fully supported integrative medicine and I feel that my plan is the best for me.  It may not be the best for someone else. The SE's were manageable, yes they sucked, but I got threw it and now feel healthier than I have felt in years, probably due to the lifestyle changes I have been making.  There are no guarantees, so I am enjoying life as much as possible and not taking it for granted anymore.

Posts.Content: May 21, 2011 03:39PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: mamaoftwo - Hi, yep, that was me.  I was clinically node negative, decided on BMX because of family history, had clear margins, cancer was in the upper left quandrant - not near the chest wall, no LVI, not multi-focal, basically a good pathology report except for 2 positive lymph nodes.   I fought the idea of radiation.  Talked with my Surgical Oncologist, got opinions from 3 Medical Oncologist and two Radiation Oncologists.   I was not mentally prepared for this, but once I met with my RO, who was the second opinion RO, he sold me on the idea based on my situation.  Since I was clinically node negative, and the positive nodes came as a big surprise to everyone and I refused the ALND, even though I did aggressive chemo and the odds were that it killed the cancer, if I had a recurrance, he said in my case we might not know until after it spread to other organs.   So I decided to just radiate the axilla and supraclavical lymph nodes, not my chest wall (cancer was on left side).  This goes outside the 'standard of care' so I am actually being treated at a diferent facility than the cancer center where the rest of my team is located.  However my RO works with my team a lot, so it was no big deal, and he also is a member of the tumor board. The majority of everyone I consulted with agreed with my decision, not all, two really thought I should not go outside the 'standard of care' and that I should radiate my chest wall too.   Once I made the decision, I felt very comfortable with it.  It actually removed some of the stress I was feeling. Every situation is different, I would suggest to get at least two opinions from radiation oncologists before making a decision that you are comfortable with.  It is your body, your decision.   Good luck and feel free to PM me.

TonLee - my understanding is that we are to avoid aluminum and anything which contains 'metals' in it.  My RO said some soaps have 'metals' in them and to stay clear of them too, he recommended Dove soap.  I was also told a combo of cornstarch and baking soda works as a deordorant and is OK to use too.  Tomorrow is my first day to get zapped.  Will be buying 25 lottery tickets on my way there.  Absolutely love that idea and hope to win some money to spend on my vacation when this is all over with.

Posts.Content: May 21, 2011 07:23PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: mamaoftwo - Like you, I fell into the 'grey area' for radiation after mastectomy.  Both RO's said that if I had gone through with the ALND, and the rest came back negative, then for me, they might have been comfortable if I chose not to do Rads, but emphasized that the studies were still ongoing and inconclusive on whether or not I could skip radiation completely.  So I cannot say with confidence what they would have recommended.   They both used the fact that I had skipped ALND as a main argument for recommending radiation, especially of the lymph nodes.  My big issue was I did not want to radiate my chest wall because I did not feel that my pathology supported Rads to my chest wall.  In fact my surgical oncologist and two medical oncologists told me, with my pathology, they did not feel that I needed to radiate my chest wall, but that I had to have a discussion regarding the radiated my lymph nodes.  Thankfully my second opinion RO respected my decision, otherwise I do not know if I would have gone through with Rads because my decision went outside of the 'standard of care' and the RO at the cancer center would not deviate from it. For me the risk of rads to my chest wall was too much vs the potential benefit.   I am 46, but with my family history of cancer, although I am BRCA neg., I wanted to keep something in my arsenal in case I got a local recurrance, because once you radiate, you usually can't radiate the area again.  I hope that with the treatments I am doing there will not be a recurrance, but I also know there are no guarantees and I had to do what I thought was best for me. Good luck, and once again, feel free to PM me.

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2011 04:52PM ProudMom_Wife wrote: Hello, I am joining the group.  I really fought hard to not have Rads, but I was sold on the need for my supraclavical and axilla lymph nodes, but declined to let them radiate my left chest wall.  I am stubborn.  Just didn't think my pathology supported it and have to go with my gut on this.  I start Rads on May 16th for 5 weeks.  But first I have my exchange surgery next week (I know it usually happens after Rads, but I had a problem with the TE and they to be removed sooner rather than later) and my port removed too.  I hate my port.  Am greatful for it, but really glad to get rid of it.  Then all the fun stuff to prepare for Rads.   pbgirl - I have read and heard from others that emu oil works great, BUT some folks can have an allergic type reaction to it, so just be aware of that.  I was thinking of trying it too but with my luck I will be one of those people who have a reaction, so I was thinking of trying non-alcoholic 100% AloeVera and Miaderm first, and if they don't work, I will try the emu oil. JulieH - Hi again.  I read that a baking powder / cornstarch combo is suppose be safe and works well.  Others have mentioned  you can use a rollon called "Crystal" which you can by at Trader Joes during Rads.  I have been using Crystal since my dx but forgot to ask my RO if I could use it during treatment or not, oops.
